Posts.Content: KelpieAU wrote: OK, don't get me wrong - I'm not looking to get pregnant while on chemo but I wanted to know if there is ladies out there that are of child bearing age and their doctors took this into consideration when deciding their chemo regimes. There are just sooooo many combinations and options and my doctors are disagreeing as to what is the best option. I'm going for a third opinion as the first and second have conflicted but it's just getting more confusing . . . . . Any opinion on this kind of issue would be appreciated :) "You only live once, but if you do it right then once is enough" Dx 5/2009, DCIS, <1cm, Stage IB, Grade 1, 0/0 nodes Dx 4/2012, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 2, 4/9 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Pre-menopausal chemo for people still wanting children. KelpieAU KelpieAU

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2012 05:21PM KelpieAU wrote: The fact that you are asking this question tells me that you would be more comfortable with a second opinion. Do it. Put your mind at ease - there is no harm in a second opinion !!
Posts.Title: looking for a little advise... smileygirl smileygirl

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2012 08:12PM KelpieAU wrote: My father didn't have breast cancer but had throat and neck cancer in 1995. Two major operations, major reconstruction operations and was told even if he quit smoking he wouldn't make it ti 2000. 2000 I had my daughter. 2003 She told him that his office stank and he quit smiking then. 2007 He went to the oncologist to check on his 'tongue' (which was actually a flap from his arm) and the oncologist said "Holy smoke Val, I thought you'd be pushing up the daisies by now !!" 2012 He is still going strong. I take great comfort that his genes are mine but I hope it is an example for you that there are a HEAP of positive stories out there !!
Posts.Title: Positive nodes with long term survival many Lily55
